questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding the physiological changes that occur during normal breathing

choices.text: During inspiration, the alveolar pressure increases to +1 cm H2O  and draws in tidal volume
The lung volume at a given pressure is higher during expiration than inspiration
The alveolar pressure is never greater than the atmospheric pressure
The air-fluid interface in the alveoli is due to surfactant which increases the surface tension

questions.solution:
The correct statement is that the lung volume at a given pressure is higher during expiration than inspiration which is explained by the hysteresis phenomenon.

The hysteresis curve demonstrates the difference between the transpulmonary pressure of inspiration and expiration. This difference is mainly due to the presence of surfactant, which forms an air-fluid interface in the alveoli, thereby reducing the surface tension (Option D). 

Transpulmonary pressure = Alveolar pressure - intrapleural pressure

The graph below shows the variation in lung volume and pressure during the respiratory cycle. 

Pleural pressure is the pressure in the thin space between the inner and outer pleural layers. This pressure is slightly negative, providing a little suction. At the beginning of inspiration in the graph, it is -5 cm H2O, which is just enough to keep the lungs open in a resting state. During inspiration, more suction pressure is required to draw air into the lungs, so the pleural pressure decreases to -7.5 cm H2O. This change in pressure is enough to draw in a tidal volume of 500 ml. It returns to baseline during expiration.

Alveolar pressure is the pressure of the air present in the alveoli. At rest, with the glottis open, the alveolar pressure equals the atmospheric pressure (zero reference pressure in airways), 0 cm H2O. During inspiration, it decreases to -1 cm H2O and draws in 500 ml of tidal volume (Option A). During expiration, it increases to +1 cm H2O and pushes out 500 ml of air. So alveolar pressure exceeds the atmospheric pressure during expiration (Option C) 

Transpulmonary pressure is the difference between alveolar pressure and pleural pressure. It is also called recoil pressure, as it is a measure of the elastic forces that tend to collapse the lungs. It is always positive in normal breathing. During inspiration, there is an increase in transpulmonary pressure as a result of which inflation of the lungs occurs. During expiration, intrapleural pressure becomes less nega­tive which decreases the transpulmonary pressure leading to a reduction in lung volume.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man with a dissecting vertebral artery aneurysm was treated with endovascular coiling. After the surgery, the patient had several episodes of prolonged apnea, mainly when asleep, often having to be "reminded" to breathe. What is the likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with apnea while sleeping after vertebral artery aneurysm surgery is suggestive of acquired Ondine syndrome, which is likely due to iatrogenic medullary injury.

Central Ondine Syndrome occurs due to injury to the brain stem, leading to loss of autonomic breathing control centers. But the cortex, which regulates the voluntary control of respiration, is normal, causing the characteristic presentation of prolonged apnea, mainly when asleep, often having to be "reminded" to breathe.

choices.text: Point A has a high PO2
Point A has a low pH
Point B has a low pH
Point B has a high PO2

questions.solution:
In the given graph, point A has a low pH.

 

This graph shows the interrelated effects of PCO2, PO2, & pH on alveolar ventilation. 

At a pH of 7.3 (A), less PCO2 is required to ventilate the alveoli as compared to point B, a pH of 7.4.

For any given value of PO2, as the PCO2 increases, the alveolar ventilation increases. 

To understand this graph, observe the pink curves; these are taken at a constant arterial PO2 value of 40, 50, 60, and 100 mm Hg, and the Pco2 is being increased. As we start increasing the Pco2, the alveolar ventilation is also increasing in a linear fashion.

Thus, the combined effects of alveolar Pco2 and Po2 on breathing are represented by this series of pink curves.

A similar pattern is observed in the series of blue curves, but at a pH of 7.3. This denotes that the curves would be displaced to the right at a higher pH and vice versa.

A 55-year-old woman was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus and was started on dapagliflozin. Which of the following statements is correct about the receptor where this drug acts?
  1. Glucose absorption is dependent on Na-K ATPase pump
  2. Sodium and glucose show antiport movement
  3. These are mainly present in the distal tubules
  4. Facilitated diffusion of glucose at the basolateral membrane
questions.solution:
The correct statements are 1 and 4.

Dapagliflozin is an SGLT (sodium-glucose co-transporter) inhibitor which inhibits glucose reabsorption in the proximal tubules, thus reducing blood glucose levels.

SGLTs are responsible for the secondary active transport of glucose, which is shown in the image below

On the basolateral side, there is active transport of sodium ions out of the cell via the Na-K ATPase pump. This depletes sodium inside the cell, creating an electrochemical gradient. 

Then, both sodium and glucose are transported together (symport movement) across the luminal membrane. 

Thus, glucose is absorbed by secondary active transport, as the energy for glucose transport is provided indirectly by the active transport of sodium. 

The glucose moves out of the cell into the blood across the basolateral membrane by facilitated diffusion mediated via GLUT.

questions.text: A patient presented with a classical finding of pulsus parvus et tardus. Which of the following pressure-volume loops will be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Pulsus parvus et tardus (i.e. a weak and late pulse) is classically associated with aortic stenosis. Amongst the given pressure-volume loops, the one that corresponds to aortic stenosis is A.  

In aortic stenosis, as there is high outflow resistance, the pressure gradient across the aortic valve is increased. The stroke volume is also severely decreased as the ventricles are not completely emptied.

The image given below shows pressure-volume loops in various valvular heart disorders.

The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling

It begins at a ventricular volume of about 50 ml (end-systolic volume) and a diastolic pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg. As venous blood flows into the ventricle from the left atrium, the ventricular volume normally increases to about 120 ml (end-diastolic volume) and the diastolic pressure rises to about 5 to 7 mm Hg.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction

The volume of the ventricle does not change because all valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle increases to equal the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) as depicted by point C.

Phase III: Period of ejection

During ejection, the systolic pressure rises even higher because of still more contraction of the ventricle. At the same time, the volume of the ventricle decreases because the aortic valve has now opened and blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

At the end of the period of ejection (point D), the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. This results in a decrease in intraventricular pressure without any change in volume. Thus, the ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 ml of blood left in the ventricle and at an atrial pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg.

The area subtended by this functional volume-pressure diagram (the shaded area, labeled EW) represents the net external work output of the ventricle during its contraction cycle.

questions.text:
A physiologist is studying the action potential of the primary cardiac pacemaker. Which of the following ion channels contribute to phase 4 in the graph given below?
  1. Hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated channels
  2. Transient type of calcium channels
  3. Dihydropyridine (DHP) calcium channel
questions.solution:
Hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) channels, also known as funny channels, and transient (T) type of calcium channels contribute to phase 4 of the action potential of the SA node. However, the DHP (L-type) calcium channels are responsible for phase 0.

The resting membrane potential (RMP) of the SA node is -55 to -60 millivolts.

Phases of this potential are: 

Phase 0: Upstroke wave. It is due to the influx of Ca2+ ions by the opening of voltage-gated L-type channels.
Phase 3: Downstroke wave. It is due to the efflux of K+ leading to repolarization.
Phase 4: Prepotential. Because of ongoing K+ efflux, hyperpolarization sets in. This makes the channel more permeable to Na+ ions and since these Na+ channels are activated during hyperpolarization, they are referred to as funny currents (Ih/If). They form the first half of the pre-potential. The second half of the prepotential is completed by the opening of the voltage-gated T-(transient) type Ca2+ channel. The slope of Phase 4 in the SA node determines the heart rate.

Related Pearl: Pacemaker potential

questions.text: Windkessel effect is seen in:
questions.solution:
The windkessel effect is seen in the large elastic arteries like the aorta.

The elasticity or windkessel effect is the exclusive property of large and elastic vessels like the aorta. These vessels when stretched undergo elastic recoil.

Aorta is stretched during systole, this expansion causes temporary storage of blood so that more blood enters the aorta. This buffer stock of blood is released during diastole, to maintain organ perfusion even during diastole. 

The image given below shows the windkessel effect seen in the aorta.

Proteins responsible for aortic elasticity are elastin and fibrillin. If elastin undergoes mutation it results in supravalvular aortic stenosis as seen in William's syndrome. If fibrillin undergoes mutation it results in dilatation of the aortic root due to cystic medial necrosis as seen in Marfan syndrome.

Aorta has the highest blood flow velocity. Blood flow velocity is inversely proportional to the cross-sectional area of the blood vessel. Therefore, the aorta has the lowest cross-sectional area.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about feedback control system is incorrect?

choices.text: Most control systems of the body act by negative feedback
Positive feedback usually promotes stability in a system
Generation of nerve actions potentials involves positive feedback
Feed-forward control is important in regulating muscle activity

questions.solution:
Positive feedback in a system generally promotes instability, rather than stability, and in some cases even death. For this reason, positive feedback, is often called a vicious cycle.

However, in some instances, positive feedback can be beneficial. One example is the nerve action potential where stimulation of the nerve membrane causes a slight leakage of sodium that causes more opening of sodium channels and this continues until an explosion of sodium entering the interior of nerve fiber creates the action potential.

Feed-forward control is used to apprise the brain whether a muscle movement is performed correctly. If not, the brain corrects the feed-forward signals that it sends to the muscle the next time the movement is required. This mechanism is often called adaptive control.

Most control systems of the body act by negative feedback.

Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is a disorder of the posterior pituitary. It is characterized by decreased ADH leading to large volumes of urine production. Patients present with excessive thirst, nocturia, and urinary frequency. 

ADH or vasopressin is the hormone secreted by the supraoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus and is stored and released by the pituitary gland. It acts on the collecting duct via aquaporins -2 and accounts for the reabsorption of about 10-15% of the total water in the tubular fluid.

questions.text: Which of the following substances follow the transportation kinetics similar to the one marked by the arrow in the graph?
questions.solution:
The arrow marked in the above-given graph relating the concentration of substances and the rate of transport indicates simple diffusion. Carbon dioxide acts through simple diffusion.

Simple diffusion refers to the process of random movement of a substance along its concentration gradient and is not carrier-mediated. In the cell, examples of molecules that can use simple diffusion to travel in and out of the cell membrane are water, oxygen, carbon dioxide, and nitrogen. They pass directly through the cell membrane without energy along the concentration gradient.

Facilitated diffusion refers to transporting the molecule from one side of the cell membrane to the other with the help of transport proteins called carriers. Molecules move from areas of high concentration to areas of low concentration. No energy input is required when carrier proteins move substances in the direction of their gradients.       

The graph below shows the relationship between concentration gradient and rate of transport in simple diffusion and facilitated diffusion.

Option A: Glucose transport by the glucose transporter is an example of facilitated diffusion which moves glucose down its concentration gradient from the ECF to the cytoplasm of the cell.

Option C: Sodium-glucose co-transporter -1 (SGLT 1) is an example of secondary active transport where more than one substance is transported against the concentration gradient using a single transport protein. The image below shows the secondary active transport of sodium and glucose using SGLT 1.

Option D: The proton pump is an example of primary active transport that transports hydrogen ions by obtaining energy from the hydrolysis of ATP to transport molecules against an electrochemical gradient.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male set on an expedition to the Himalayas and on climbing due to intense cold temperature his body started shivering to increase the core body temperature. Which of the following nuclei sends the impulses in the above scenario?
questions.solution:
Posterior hypothalamic nuclei are involved in the process of shivering. 

The primary motor center for shivering is located in the dorsomedial portion of the posterior hypothalamus near the wall of the third ventricle. This area is usually inhibited by the heat center (located in the anterior hypothalamus) but is stimulated by the cold signals from the skin and the spinal cord. 

The excitation of this center ultimately leads to increased skeletal muscle tone which facilitates the activity of anterior motor neurons and the feedback oscillation from the muscle spindle stretch reflex. 

During maximum shivering, the body temperature can rise to 4-5 times normal.

Other options:

Option A: Anterior hypothalamic nuclei are referred to as the heat center and are activated when the temperature is high leading to sweating.

Option B: Lateral hypothalamic nuclei regulate appetite and its stimulation leads to increased hunger and increased food intake. 

Option C: Supra chiasmatic hypothalamic nuclei regulate circadian rhythm.

questions.text: Which of the following substance is responsible for regulation of iron absorption in the duodenum and where is it secreted from?
questions.solution:
Hepcidin, a small peptide, is produced by the liver which regulates the iron absorption in the duodenum. 

Hepcidin is synthesized in the liver in response to increased intrahepatic iron stores. It binds to ferroportin on the basal surface of the enterocyte and inhibits iron absorption into the plasma. When hepcidin levels rise, more iron is trapped in the enterocytes called mucosal iron. This is eliminated by the sloughing of the duodenal epithelium. 

Hepcidin also inhibits the release of iron from the macrophages, which is used by the erythroid precursors in making hemoglobin. In any inflammatory conditions, some inflammatory mediators lead to increased hepcidin levels causing decreased release of iron, in part leading to anemia of chronic disease.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man was brought to the OPD by his daughter, who complained that the patient was unable to see. The optic disc was normal. When asked to identify a few things by looking at them, he was unable to do so and started confabulating to cover it up. Which of the following Brodmann areas are responsible for the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario refers to a patient with cortical blindness (Anton syndrome) and is due to the lesions affecting the primary visual cortex or Brodmann’s area 17 bilaterally. 

Anton syndrome is characterized by cortical blindness with confabulation. The patient denies loss of vision (known as visual anosognosia) and defends it by confabulation even when there is obvious evidence of visual loss and cortical blindness.

Bilateral occipital damage with damage to the primary visual cortex leads to cortical blindness. The primary visual cortex lies in the calcarine fissure area and the visual pathway terminates here. It has six major layers histologically which helps in binocular vision. The primary visual cortex is also called visual area I or the striate cortex because this area has a grossly striated appearance.

Other options: 

Option B: Bilateral damage to Areas 18 and 19 can lead to a condition known as visual agnosia, where the patient can see objects but cannot recognize or identify them. While this could explain the inability to identify objects, it does not account for the patient's overall inability to see. Confabulation might occur in visual agnosia, but the normal optic disc combined with an inability to see altogether points more toward cortical blindness, which is associated with bilateral damage to Area 17.

Option C: Damage to the right-sided Area 17 (unilateral damage) typically affects the visual processing of the left visual field, leading to visual field defects such as left homonymous hemianopia. However, it would not result in complete blindness or the inability to recognize objects, as the left Area 17 would still be functional. The patient's symptoms of being unable to see and confabulating to cover up the inability to identify objects suggest a more widespread issue, consistent with bilateral rather than unilateral damage.

Option D: Areas 18 and 19 are involved in higher-order visual processing, integrating visual information to help recognize and interpret objects, form, and movement. Damage to the right-sided Areas 18 and 19 could impair specific aspects of visual processing, such as object recognition or spatial orientation, particularly in the left visual field. However, such damage would not typically result in complete blindness or the global inability to identify objects. Instead, it would likely result in visual agnosia for objects in the left visual field, but not total visual impairment or confabulation to the extent described in the patient’s case.

questions.text: A patient with hematemesis due to esophageal varices was given terlipressin, which mediates its action via the vasopressin V1 receptor. This receptor is an example of G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR), which works as shown below. Which subtype of GPCR is it?
questions.solution:
The answer is Option C-Gq.

G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 7 times. They also serve as receptors for various peptide hormones, neurotransmitters, amino acids, etc.

Subtypes of GPCRs are distinguished by their alpha subunits. The important subtypes of GPCRs are Gs, Gp, Gq, and Go.

GPCRs act via various second messengers. The important ones with their action on the effector are:

  • Gs causes activation of adenylyl cyclase and results in Ca2+ channel opening.
  • Gi causes inhibition of adenylyl cyclase and results in K+ channel opening.
  • G0 causes Ca2+ channel inactivation.
  • Gq causes activation of phospholipase C, which generates the second messenger's inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). The water-soluble IP3 diffuses to the cytosol and mobilizes Ca2+ from endoplasmic reticulum depots.

questions.text: A carpenter sustained a hit to his thumb by a hammer while working. Following this, he developed a poorly localised dull aching pain.  What is the type of nerve fibre carrying this pain?
questions.solution:
The poorly localised dull aching pain experienced after a hit by a heavy object like a hammer is carried by C fibres.

C-dorsal root fibres are unmyelinated fibres found mainly in the deep somatic structures such as the muscles and joints. They are activated by thermal, mechanical or chemical stimuli that result in poor localization and slow, dull pain. The conducting rate of these fibres is 0.5 to 2 m/s.

Another type of nerve fibre responsible for pain sensation is Aδ fibres. They are myelinated fibres responsible for first pain also called fast pain (conduction velocity 6 to 30 m/s). These fibres get activated under thermal or mechanical stimuli and cause a short-lasting pricking type of pain that can be localized. They are mainly found in superficial structures such as the skin.

questions.text: A physiologist is studying the structure of a skeletal muscle sarcomere. He takes a cross-section of sarcomere at a level that appears dark as shown by the arrow in the image below. What will he find?
questions.solution:
The cross-section of sarcomere at a level that appears dark as shown by the arrow marks the A band. It consists of myosin surrounded by actin. 

Sarcomere is the area between two dark Z-lines. It is composed of thick filaments like myosin and thin filaments like actin, tropomyosin, troponin. 

The difference in the refractive index of various muscle fibers leads to cross-striations when viewed under a microscope. The various levels of section of the sarcomere and the myofilaments they are composed of are as follows: 

Sections Myofilaments
I band Only actin
A band (exculding H zone) Actin and myosin
AI junction Actin and myosin
H zone Only myosin
M line Thick filament linked with accessory proteins

Note: Pseudo-H zone is referred to the lighter areas around the M-line including the M-line.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: A person involved in a road traffic accident has a peculiar posture with clenched hands and flexed upper limbs. The lower limbs are extended with toes pointing inwards. Which of the following is associated with this posture?
questions.solution:
The described posture is seen in decorticate rigidity caused by lesions rostral to the midbrain. There is flexion of the upper limbs at the elbow and extension of the lower limbs. Flexion is due to rubrospinal excitation of the muscles of the upper extremities.

Other options:

Option B: In decerebrate rigidity, the lesion involves motor tracts caudal to the midbrain and involves the rubrospinal tract. Hence, all four limbs are extended in this condition.

Note: Posturing in decerebrate rigidity becomes exaggerated if the anterior lobe of the cerebellum is damaged and this is called decerebellate rigidity.

Option C: Uncal herniation is associated with decerebrate posturing.

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, the patient sustained an injury to the right half of the spinal cord. Which of the following features is likely to be seen in this patient below the level of the lesion?

choices.text: Loss of pain and temperature on the right side
Muscle weakness in the left side of the body
Loss of vibration and proprioception on the right side
Loss of vibration and proprioception on the left side

questions.solution:
The feature likely to be seen in this patient below the level of the spinal cord lesion is loss of vibration and proprioception of the right side.

Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown- Séquard syndrome. The features likely to be seen here are - 

  • Ipsilateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion. It occurs as a result of damage to the fasciculus gracilus or fasciculus cuneatus
  • Ipsilateral muscle weakness as a result of damage to the corticospinal tract
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the lesion as a result of damage to the spinothalamic tract.

Corticosteroids administered soon after the injury help in preventing the damage.

Other important syndromes related to the ascending tracts of the spinal cord are

  • Paresthesias are the abnormal sensation of numbness or tingling sensation in the body. It is usually caused due to the irritation of the primary somatosensory cortex.
  • Thalamic pain syndrome is characterized by chronic pain on the side of the body contralateral to the stroke. It occurs during the recovery from the thalamic infarct.

questions.text: A lady sustained head trauma and was evaluated for intracranial hemorrhage. Her speech was fluent but comprehension was affected. Which area of the brain is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
A lady who had sustained head trauma and has fluent speech but affected comprehension is most likely to have Wernicke's aphasia. The area affected is the posterior superior temporal gyrus, referred to as the sensory speech area or Wernicke's area. 

Intracerebral hemorrhage and neoplasm are some of the causes that can lead to Wernicke's aphasia. Language output is fluent but the comprehension is affected. There is a jumbling of words. The ability to understand spoken and written word is retained but the interpretation is affected.

Other options:

Options B and C: Damage to the premotor and prefrontal areas of the cerebral cortex results in Broca's aphasia. In this condition, the speech is non-fluent and interrupted by many word-finding pauses. The speech is telegraphic but informative. This is also called motor aphasia.

Option D: Damage to the arcuate fasciculus has been implicated in conduction aphasia which results in impaired repetition.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with complaints of reduced vision in the right eye. Kinetic perimetry revealed right homonymous hemianopia. What is the most likely location of the defect in the optic pathway?
questions.solution:
The most likely defect in this patient presenting with right homonymous hemianopia is in the left optic tract, marked as 3. Homonymous hemianopia involves a loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes.

Other options:

Structure marked as 1 is the left optic nerve. A lesion in this part leads to blindness in the left eye.

Structure marked as 2 is the right optic nerve. A lesion in this part leads to blindness in the right eye.

Structure marked as 4 is the right optic tract. A lesion in this part leads to left homonymous hemianopia.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of cholecystokinin?

choices.text: Relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi

questions.solution:
Cholecystokinin(CCK) inhibits gastric emptying, it does not stimulate it.

CCK is secreted by I cells in the mucosa of the upper small intestine. It is also found in nerves in the distal ileum and colon, and neurons in the cerebral cortex. Its functions include:

  • Stimulation of pancreatic enzyme secretion (option A)
  • Gallbladder contraction
  • Relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi to allow the flow of bile and pancreatic juice into the intestinal lumen (option D)
  • Inhibits gastric emptying
  • Increases the synthesis of enterokinase
  • Enhances the motility of the small intestine and colon (option C)
  • Increases the action of secretin, alkalizing the pancreatic juice
  • Trophic effect on the pancreas

The secretion of CCK is increased by:

  • Products of digestion like peptides and amino acids coming in contact with the intestinal mucosa
  • Presence of fatty acids containing >10 C atoms in the duodenum
  • CCK-releasing peptide and monitor peptide

Bile and pancreatic juice enter the duodenum in response to CCK, enhancing the digestion of protein and fat. The products of this digestion stimulate further CCK secretion, as positive feedback. However, this positive feedback is terminated when the products of digestion move further down the GI tract.

questions.text: During research on male contraceptives, a group of scientists was studying the blood-testis barrier.  This barrier is located between:
questions.solution:
The blood-testis barrier is located between Sertoli cells and Sertoli cells.

Sertoli cells are linked by tight junctions, the strongest intercellular barrier in the body. This arrangement forms the blood-testes barrier.

Important functions of the blood testes barrier are:

  • It prevents the passing of large molecules from interstitial tissue and basal compartment to the tubular lumen.
  • It helps in maintaining the composition of the tubular fluid.
  • It protects the developing sperms from immunological attack and blood borne noxious agents.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought by his family with complaints that he is seeing children run in the room who do not exist. He has also been reprimanded at work for not completing his assignments. He has a flat affect and utters several inappropriate words while talking. His family says that they had first noticed the change in his personality 7 months back. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Decreased activity in which of the following pathways is associated with his flat affect?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of Schizophrenia. Decreased activity of the mesocortical pathway is responsible for the negative symptoms of schizophrenia.

Important dopaminergic pathways are:

  • Mesolimbic pathway - Increased activity responsible for positive symptoms of schizophrenia.
  • Mesocortical pathway - Decreased activity responsible for negative symptoms of schizophrenia.
  • Nigrostriatal pathway - Decreased activity causes extrapyramidal symptoms. Degeneration of this is responsible for Parkinson's disease.
  • Tuberoinfundibular pathway - Decreased activity causes an increase in prolactin.

Diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia (DSM V):

The DSM-5 criteria to diagnose schizophrenia require a total duration of 6 months. Within these 6 months, there must be at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms (overt psychotic symptoms) where 2 or more of the following have to be present : 

a.Delusion

b.Hallucination

c.Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)

d.Disorganized behavior

e.Affective flattening or other negative symptoms


At least one must be among the a, b, or c.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male patient, with a history of upper respiratory tract infection, presents with rapidly progressing, symmetric, ascending paralysis since 7 days. The knee jerk reflex is absent bilaterally. Investigations show elevated CSF protein levels. Which of the following is affected by this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of progressive, ascending, symmetrical weakness, following a respiratory infection is suggestive of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). It is an immune-mediated disease, where autoimmune cells attack the myelin proteins of the peripheral nervous system. 

GBS is caused by an immune response and/or antibodies produced against external antigens (e.g. Campylobacter jejuni, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, and human herpesvirus [HHV]) introduced by infections  or by vaccines such as influenza vaccine. These autoantibodies target similar proteins present in the person's nervous tissue—a phenomenon called molecular mimicry.

GBS manifests as a rapidly evolving motor paralysis with areflexia (or hyporeflexia), with or without sensory disturbance. It is an ascending paralysis that affects the lower limbs more than the upper limbs. It can also affect the cranial nerves, leading to features of bulbar paralysis like difficulty articulating words and excessive drooling.

Glia (Greek: glue) are cells that help in communication within the CNS. They are classified into 2 types according to their sizes—microglia and macroglia. Macroglia are of 3 types—astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and Schwann cells.

Schwann cells and oligodendrocytes are responsible for myelin formation around the axons of the peripheral nerves and nerves in the brain and spinal cord respectively. Myelin protein zero (P0) and hydrophobic protein PMP22 are components of the myelin sheath in the peripheral nervous system. They are affected in different conditions: 

  • Multiple sclerosis - Patchy destruction of the myelin sheath in the central nervous system
  • Guillain-Barre syndrome - Autoimmune destruction of myelin protein genes (P0 and PMP22)
  • Charcot-Marrie-Tooth disease - Mutations in the myelin protein genes (P0 and PMP22) causing disruption of myelin and axonal degeneration.

questions.text: During an experiment, it was found that a patient's kidneys consumed 70 mL of oxygen per minute. If the oxygen concentration in renal artery and renal vein is 19 mL/dL of blood and 14 mL/dL of blood respectively, calculate the blood flow across the kidneys.
questions.solution:
Fick principle can be applied in this question to determine the blood flow across the patient's kidneys.  

Blood flow across the organ = Oxygen consumption by the organ / [O2] artery - [O2] vein

Hence blood flow across this patient's kidneys = 70 mL/min / 19-14 mL/dL

                                = 1400 mL/min

Cardiac output = Oxygen consumption / [O2] pulmonary vein - [O2] pulmonary artery

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant with 46XX karyotype is born with genitalia as shown in the image below. Further clinical and laboratory investigations reveal that the child has adrenal hyperplasia with glucocorticoid deficiency and mineralocorticoid excess. Which enzyme is likely to be deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
Ambiguous genitalia (androgen excess), with features of glucocorticoid deficiency and mineralocorticoid excess, suggests that the enzyme 11β-hydroxylase is likely to be deficient. 

11β-Hydroxylase helps in the conversions of 11-deoxycorticosterone (DOC) and 11-deoxycortisol to corticosterone and cortisol, respectively. Therefore, a defect in this enzyme results in increased accumulation of 11-deoxycorticosterone (DOC), and 11-deoxycortisol, and decreased production of corticosterone and cortisol. The accumulated steroids are converted to androgens. The accumulated DOC has excess mineralocorticoid activity. Therefore, the patient will have features of glucocorticoid deficiency, with androgen and mineralocorticoid excess.

Other options:

Option A- 21-Hydroxylase enzyme converts progesterone and 17-hydroxyprogesterone to 11-deoxycorticosterone and 11-deoxycortisol. Therefore, if this enzyme is deficient, there is an increased accumulation of the precursors and decreased production of cortisol and aldosterone. The precursors do not have mineralocorticoid activity but can be converted to androgens. Therefore the patients will present with features of glucocorticoid deficiency, mineralocorticoid deficiency, and adrenal androgen excess.

Option C- 17α-Hydroxylase is the enzyme that is required for the conversion of mineralocorticoid precursors to the glucocorticoid and androgen precursors. Therefore, deficiency of this enzyme will lead to increased mineralocorticoid and its precursors and decreased cortisol and androgens. Therefore patients will have mineralocorticoid excess with glucocorticoid and androgen deficiency.

Option D- Cholesterol desmolase is required for the conversion of cholesterol to pregnenolone. This is the precursor of all the steroid hormones. Therefore patients will present with deficiencies of all three steroid hormones.

Note- Any of these enzyme deficiencies can cause adrenal hyperplasia. The levels of Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) are increased due to a decrease in the cortisol levels. This ACTH stimulates hyperplasia.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman has hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and decreased urinary phosphate excretion. The injection​ of parathyroid hormone (PTH) causes an increase in urinary cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP). The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is hypoparathyroidism after thyroid surgery.

Low blood Ca2+ and high blood phosphate are consistent with hypoparathyroidism.

Lack of parathyroid hormone (PTH) decreases bone resorption, decreases renal reabsorption of Ca2+, and increases renal reabsorption of phosphate (causing low urinary phosphate).

Because the patient responded to exogenous PTH with an increase in urinary cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP), the G protein coupling the PTH receptor to adenylate cyclase is apparently normal. Consequently, pseudohypoparathyroidism is excluded.

Vitamin D intoxication would cause hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia, while Vitamin D deficiency would cause hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia.

Hypoparathyroidism: It is most commonly a result of thyroid surgery, or it is congenital.

It is characterized by the following:

  • Decreased serum Ca2+ (hypocalcemia) and tetany

questions.text: In the given nerve action potential curve, which point represents the return of  Na+ channels to the closed state?
questions.solution:
At point C, Na+ channels close and K+ channels open, causing repolarization due to K+ efflux. 

The sequence of events occurring during a nerve action potential is as shown below:

Point A - Resting potential. A state where both Na+ and K+ channels are closed. 

Point B - Threshold potential. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus and Na+ influx occurs. The initiation of action potential occurs only after a certain potential is reached, called the threshold potential.

Point C - Peak of action potential. The sodium influx causes the opening of more Na+ channels through a positive feedback loop. Rapid depolarization occurs. At point C, Na+ channels close and K+ channels open, causing repolarization due to K+ efflux. 

Point D - Repolarization and hyperpolarization due to continued  K+ efflux.

Point E - After Hyperpolarization. The K+ channels slowly return to the closed state, causing after-hyperpolarization. Na+ channels are reset and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus.

Both channels then close and the membrane returns to resting membrane potential.

questions.text: A premature newborn is shifted to NICU with tachypnea, audible respiratory grunting, intercostal retractions, and cyanosis. An X-ray revealed ground glass opacities and air bronchograms. Which of the following cells marked in the respiratory epithelium below are involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of acute respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). Type II pneumocytes, which are marked as 2 in the above image, are damaged in RDS.

RDS is seen in premature infants, due to the decreased production and secretion of the lung surfactant. 

The risk of developing RDS is further increased by:

  • Maternal diabetes
  • Cesarean delivery
  • Multiple births
  • Asphyxia
  • Cold stress
  • Maternal history of previously affected infants.

Clinical features of RDS include tachypnea, audible respiratory grunting, intercostal and subcostal retractions, nasal flaring, and cyanosis.

A diagnosis can be made with the presence of ground-glass opacity, low lung volumes, and air bronchograms on a chest x-ray, along with blood gas findings like hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and metabolic acidosis.

Administration of antenatal glucocorticoids can increase surfactant production and reduce the risk of RDS.

The surfactant consists of phospholipid dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine, also called lecithin, surface apoproteins, and calcium ions. This phospholipid is synthesized in type II pneumocytes in the endoplasmic reticulum, following which, it is processed in the Golgi apparatus and packed in the lamellar bodies. These surface-active agents are then released into the alveoli.

The surfactant helps to reduce the alveolar surface tension and by doing so, helps prevent their collapse. It also reduces the effort required by the respiratory muscles to expand the lungs.

However, as secretion of surfactant does not begin until the sixth and seventh months of gestation, it is very likely that in a premature infant, there is little to no surfactant present. This greatly increases the tendency of the lungs to collapse, leading to respiratory distress syndrome in the newborn.

The above clinical scenario, with the typical physical appearance and presence of pituitary adenoma, is suggestive of Cushing's disease. Early morning ACTH levels in patients with Cushing's disease would be much higher than those of normal individuals. 

Cushing’s disease is caused by an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. The increased ACTH causes increased cortisol production, about three times more than the normal level.

questions.text: Which of the following anterior pituitary hormones share a common Alpha(α) subunit that is the product of a single gene?
questions.solution:
FSH, LH, and TSH hormones of anterior pituitary share a common Alpha(α) subunit.

Five types of secretory cells have been identified in the anterior pituitary. They are

  • Somatotropes: which secrete growth hormone
  • Lactotropes (also called mammotropes): which secrete prolactin
  • Corticotropes: which secrete ACTH
  • Thyrotropes: which secrete TSH

It is notable that the three pituitary glycoprotein hormones i.e FSH, LH, and TSH while being made up of two subunits, all share a common α subunit that is the product of a single gene and has the same amino acid composition in each hormone, although their carbohydrate residues vary. 

The α subunit must be combined with the β subunit characteristic of each hormone for maximal physiologic activity.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease has a report showing HCO3- = 23 mEq/L, Na+ = 145 mEq/L, Cl- = 100 mEq/L. Calculate the anion gap in this patient.
questions.solution:

Normally, in the serum, the total number of cations is equal to the total number of anions. But, a few of the anions (lactate, phosphate, and sulfate) cannot be measured and this is called an anion gap. It is the difference between measured cations and measured anions and is estimated as:

Plasma anion gap = [Na+ ] − [(HCO3− ) + (Cl− )]

Substituting the values = 145−23−100= 22 mEq/L

The normal anion gap ranges between 8-16 mEq/L.

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding the graph shown below are true except?

choices.text: The first urge to void is felt at a volume of about 300 mL
The sense of fullness is felt at a volume of about 400 mL
The flatness of segment Ib is due to law of Laplace

questions.solution:
The above graph is a cystometrogram. The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL and not at 300 mL.

Cystometrogram is a  plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder. The curve shows three segments:

  • Ia where an initial slight rise in pressure when the first increments in the volume are produced
  • Ib where a long, nearly flat segment as further increments are produced
  • II where a sudden, sharp rise in pressure as the micturition reflex is triggered

The flatness of segment Ib is a demonstration of the law of Laplace. The law of Laplace states that the pressure (P) in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension (T) divided by the radius (R). This is expressed as P= 2T/R

In the blad­der, the tension increases as the bladder get filled. But as the radius too increases the increase in pressure is slight until the bladder is relatively full. The marked sense of fullness is felt at a bladder volume of about 400 mL.

The graph shown below explains the change in volume of the lung, as the intrapleural pressure increases.

Compliance is increased in normal aging lungs and pulmonary emphysema due to decreased elastic recoil of lungs (tendency of the lungs to become less stretched).

Compliance is decreased in fibrosis, pulmonary edema, and unventilated lungs due to alveoli being prevented from getting inflated.

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.

questions.text: A normal healthy adult participated in a respiratory study that was conducted to understand the respiratory functions. In the upright position, an increase in all of the following parameters can be seen with respect to the base of the lungs except?
questions.solution:
In the upright position, an increase in the ventilation-perfusion ratio (V/Q ratio) is not seen with respect to the base of the lungs. At the base of the lung, the V/Q ratio is decreased. 

V/Q ratio is the ratio of alveolar ventilation (V) to pulmonary blood flow (Q) for the lungs at rest. The average value of the V/Q ratio throughout the lungs is 0.8. When this ratio is mismatched, it can cause CO2 retention (when solely, ventilation is impaired) or lowered arterial O2 (when perfusion is impaired). 

Normally, in the upright position, the V/Q ratio in the normal lungs markedly undergoes changes from the apex to the base due to the effect of gravity as shown below - 

At the base of the lung:

Both ventilation and perfusion increase since the flow is towards gravity.

Increased ventilation is due to the increase in intrapleural pressure compared to the apex, thereby making the intrapulmonary intrapleural pressure difference less at the base. Thus, due to this low-pressure difference, the lung is less expanded compared to the apex. This makes the ventilation per unit volume rise as the lung expansion is relatively small. 

The alveolar pressure also decreases thus reducing the compression of the vessels and increasing the pulmonary blood flow at the base. An increase in perfusion is more than an increase in ventilation, i.e., denominator increases. Hence, the ratio decreases.

At the apex (against gravity):

Both ventilation and perfusion decrease since the flow is against gravity.

The reason for decreased ventilation is that at the start of inspiration, intrapleural pressure is more negative thus making the intrapulmonary intrapleural pressure difference increase at the apex. The apex is above the level of the heart and capillary pressure at the apex is close to atmospheric pressure thus decreasing the blood flow. But, a decrease in perfusion is higher than a decrease in ventilation. Hence, the ratio increases.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient with a history of type-1 DM has not taken her insulin for three days. She is diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis. Which of the following oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curves would be similar to that of the patient?
questions.solution:
In this patient with diabetic ketoacidosis, who would have a low blood pH, the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve would show a right shift, as seen in graph 1.

Hemoglobin exists in 2 forms in the blood. The deoxyhemoglobin form is called the taut or T form. This hemoglobin has a low affinity for oxygen. The oxyhemoglobin form is called the relaxed or R form. This hemoglobin has a high affinity for oxygen. 

In deoxyhemoglobin, the globin units are tightly bound in a tense (T) configuration, which reduces the affinity of the molecule for O2. When O2 is first bound, the bonds holding the globin units are released, producing a relaxed (R) configuration, which exposes more O2-binding sites. The net result is a 500-fold increase in O2 affinity. This increasing affinity is called positive cooperativity. In other words, the combination of the first heme in the tetramer with O2 increases the affinity of the second heme for O2, and oxygenation of the second increases the affinity of the third, thereby resulting in the characteristic sigmoid shape of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.

If the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve is shifted to the right, it means that the affinity of Hb for O2 has become less, which favors O2 delivery. This means a higher P50, means higher PO2 is required to maintain 50% saturation (R - right shift releases oxygen).

If the curve is shifted to the left, it means that affinity has increased for O2 (which favors O2 binding) i.e. lower P50 value. (L-Left shift Leashes oxygen).

questions.text: Which of the following molecular motors is mainly responsible for the ciliary movement?
questions.solution:
The interaction of the axonemal dynein with the microtubules is responsible for the ciliary movement.

Molecular motors are ATPases that move proteins, organelles, and other cellular components collectively referred to as 'cargo' to various parts of the cell. They convert the energy of ATP into movement along the cytoskeleton, taking their cargo with them. There are three superfamilies of molecular motors, which include dynein, kinesin and myosin.

Dyneins:

  • They have two heads, with their neckpieces embedded in a complex of proteins.
  • Cytoplasmic dyneins are similar to conventional kinesin, except they move particles and membranes to the minus (–) end of the microtubules.
  • Axonemal dyneins are present with the axonemes of the cilia. An axoneme consists of a unique arrangement of nine outer microtubule doublets and two inner microtubules ("9+2" arrangement). The coordinated dynein–microtubule interactions within the axoneme are responsible for the ciliary and sperm movement.

Kinesin:

  • The conventional form of kinesin is a double-headed molecule that moves its cargo toward the plus (“+”) ends of microtubules.
  • Some kinesins are associated with mitosis and meiosis.
  • Other kinesins perform different functions, and may also move cargo to the minus (“–”) end of microtubules.

Myosins:

  • There are about 18 classes of myosins.
  • The heads of some myosin molecules (myosin II) bind to actin and produce motion by bending their neck regions.
  • Some myosin molecules (myosin V) may move the cargo, by walking along microfilaments, one head after the other.

Other options:

Option C: Dynamin is a GTPase responsible for clathrin-mediated endocytosis.

questions.text: What is the effect on resting membrane potential when the serum potassium is 3 mEq/L?

choices.text: RMP becomes more negative, cell is more excitable
RMP becomes more positive, cell is more excitable
RMP becomes more negative, cell is less excitable
RMP becomes more positive, cell is less excitable

questions.solution:
A potassium level of 3 mEq/L means there is hypokalemia. The resting membrane potential becomes more negative and the cell is less excitable in hypokalemia.

The resting membrane potential represents an equilibrium situation where the concentration gradient of ions across the membrane is equal and opposite to the electrical gradients. At a normal potassium concentration of 3.5–5.5 mEq/L, the equilibrium potential for potassium is −90 mV. This is close to the resting membrane potential of neurons, which is about –70 mV.

A decrease in the extracellular sodium concentration reduces the size of the action potential but has little effect on the resting membrane potential. However, the intracellular and extracellular potassium (K+) concentrations are the major determinants of the RMP.

This is because

  • At rest, there are more open K+ channels than Na+ channels; therefore, the membrane permeability of K+ is greater.
  • The RMP is close to the equilibrium potential of K+.

In hypokalemia, the extracellular level of K+ is reduced. Thus, the RMP is reduced or becomes more negative and the nerve is hyperpolarized.

In hyperkalemia, the extracellular level of K+ is increased. Thus, the RMP moves closer to the threshold to elicit an action potential, leading to a more excitable nerve. This means the RMP has become more positive.

questions.text: A patient who had previously been intubated while admitted to the intensive care unit was found to have tracheal stenosis during his follow-up visits. Which of the following graphs would represent the flow-volume loop in this patient?
questions.solution:
The graph representing the flow-volume loop in this patient with tracheal stenosis would be graph 3, or option C. 

When there is fixed central airway obstruction, there is obstruction and limitation of airflow during both inspiration and expiration. This leads to the flattening of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs of the flow-volume loop, as observed in tracheal stenosis.

Other options:

Option A: Image 1 shows airflow limitation and flattening in the inspiratory limb of the loop. It is seen in conditions responsible for variable upper airway obstruction like vocal fold paralysis, and extrathoracic tracheomalacia.

Option B: Image 2 shows airflow limitation and flattening in the expiratory limb of the loop. This is seen in conditions responsible for variable lower airway obstruction like tracheomalacia of intrathoracic airway or bronchogenic cysts.

Option D: Image 4 shows a concave upward, pattern in the expiratory limb. This is also a called "scooped-out" or "coved" pattern and is observed in cases responsible for airflow obstruction at any transmural pressure, like in asthma or chronic bronchitis.

A sawtooth pattern of the loop consists of small, rapid oscillations in airflow during both expiration and inspiration. It is seen in neuromuscular diseases, Parkinson's disease, laryngeal dyskinesia, pedunculated tumours of the upper airway, tracheobronchomalacia, and obstructive sleep apnea.

questions.text: The negative feedback control of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) secretion is regulated by which of the following functions of the Sertoli cells?
questions.solution:
Inhibin synthesized by Sertoli cells inhibits the release of FSH from the anterior pituitary.

The male hypothalamic-pituitary axis is regulated by negative feedback through two mechanisms. First, testosterone inhibits the secretion of GnRH from the hypothalamus and LH from the anterior pituitary, reducing the frequency and amplitude of GnRH pulses. Second, Sertoli cells produce inhibin, a glycoprotein that inhibits FSH secretion by the anterior pituitary. Thus, Sertoli cells regulate spermatogenesis by producing inhibin, which acts as a marker of spermatogenic activity.

Other options:

Option B and C: Testosterone is aromatized in the ovaries in women. Additionally, it only inhibits the release of LH from the anterior pituitary not FSH.

Option D: Tight junctions between adjacent Sertoli cells near the basal lamina form a blood-testis barrier that prevents many large molecules from passing from the interstitial tissue. However, this has no role to play in the inhibition of FSH secretion.
